intro: Behen fabarius, commonly known as the Indian mustard or Brassica juncea, is an annual herbaceous plant native to South Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with alternate, pinnately compound leaves. Its seeds are used in traditional medicine and as a source of oil, while the leaves are consumed as a vegetable. The plant thrives in temperate climates and is cultivated for both agricultural and medicinal purposes.
